source.raw_text:
A hip swing, often referring to dynamic leg swings or the fundamental hip hinge, primarily targets the posterior chain (glutes, hamstrings, lower back) for strength and the hip flexors and abdominals for dynamic mobility, using a pattern of hip flexion (bringing thigh to torso) and extension (driving thigh back) while stabilizing the core for control, crucial for power and preventing spinal strain in daily life. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Posterior Chain): 

    • Glutes (Gluteus Maximus): Extend the hip to drive the leg forward/upward and back. 
    • Hamstrings: Assist glutes in hip extension and stabilize the knee. 

• Stabilizers & Synergists: 

    • Erector Spinae: Support and maintain a neutral, stable spine, especially in hip hinges. 
    • Core (Transverse Abdominis): Deep abdominal muscles that brace the pelvis and spine for stability. 
    • Hip Flexors (Iliacus, Psoas): Engage to lift the thigh towards the torso (hip flexion) during the forward swing. 
    • Quadriceps: Help stabilize the knee joint during movement. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  

Movement Pattern 

1. The Hip Hinge (Foundation): Involves bending at the hips, not the waist, with a neutral spine, pushing your hips backward as if closing a car door with your butt. 
2. Dynamic Swing (Leg Swings): A controlled, repetitive motion where the leg swings forward (hip flexion) and backward (hip extension). 
3. Core Engagement: The abs and spinal erectors work isometrically (without changing length) to keep the torso upright and prevent the lower back from rounding or hyperextending. 
4. Balance & Control: You're moving the femur (thigh bone) within the hip socket, emphasizing glute and hamstring power on the extension and hip flexor control on the flexion. [1, 2, 4, 7, 8, 9]  

Key Benefits 

• Strength: Develops the posterior chain, vital for lifting and explosive movements. 
• Mobility: Improves hip flexibility and range of motion. 
• Injury Prevention: Teaches you to move from your hips, protecting your lower back. [1, 4, 7, 10, 11]
